channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: C, C++, and Perl Software Engineers, Let’s Keep the Internet Safe. UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: A leading digital safeguarding solutions provider is looking for a software engineer experienced in C, C++, or Perl. You’ll have strong Linux knowledge and a methodical approach to problem solving that you use to investigate, replicate, and address customer issues. Your keen understanding of firewalls, proxies, Iptables, Squid, VPNs/IPSec and HTTP(S) will be key to your success at this company.

item.title: Adventure! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Enter our international client: online trading is their game, and they’re looking for Perl folks with passion, drive, and an appreciation for new experiences.

item.title: Senior Perl Developer with Cross-Trained Chops. UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great CPAN modules released last week.

item.title: Number Challenges
item.description: Keeping the Perl flag flying on dev.to for so long. Thank you.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #210
item.description: Cool task analysis that makes it fun to read. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Kill and Collide!
item.description: Go and play with the solution online. Interesting discussion too.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 210
item.description: Master of one-liner is once again up for the game. I really enjoy the creative side of it.

item.title: I didn't get very well
item.description: Lack of clarity in the task created so much confusions. Still we have solution ...

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 210
item.description: Another extraordinary piece of art by James. These need to be kept in safe.

item.title: PWC210 - Number Collision
item.description: To me, the question section of the post is most entertaing. So much to learn from the post every week. Well done.

item.title: PWC210 - Kill and Win
item.description: Too many holes in the task but you still have solution from Flavio. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Killing Numbers
item.description: The quality blog post with graphical presentation is highly recommended. Go for it.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 210
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Kill and Win" and "Number Collision" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 211
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Toeplitz Matrix" and "Split Same Average". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Weather::WeatherKit and Weather::Astro7Timer
item.description: Useful addition to the CPAN, if you want to access WeatherKit.

item.title: Encoding is hard
item.description: Encoding is not my favourite subject but here it is discussed in simple language that makes it easy to follow.

item.title: Binary data in jq
item.description: If you ever played with jq then this is for you when dealing with binary data.

item.title: PNG Attachments in Romeo
item.description: Here we get the how-to do PNG attachements in Romeo. This will keep you busy.

item.title: Playing with PNG files
item.description: It is not easy to play with PNG or any other images but here you get insight for fun. Nice work.

item.title: Graph - Weekly Travelling in CPAN
item.description: Continued with the weekly travelling, here we got another brilliant piece of work. Highly recommended.

item.title: Experiments in Overloading
item.description: A very interesting use of case of overloading "0+" being discussed. You really don't want to skip it.

item.title: #610 - Perl and TPF
item.description:
Hi there,

Belated Happy Ramadan to those who celebrate the holy month.

To me and most of us, TPF, is the parent body who supports the language. With the emergence of Raku, it is now referred as TPRF (The Perl and Raku Foundation). There have been many positive changes brought by the parent body. One of them is the creation of Perl Steering Council and we even get the weekly update too. You can checkout the latest update from PSC.

The change in name reminds me when I had to change the name Perl Weekly Challenge to The Weekly Challenge to accommodate Raku and many other languages. Even today, I use the term Team PWC as I find it hard to move on. The best part is the team shares ideas from other languages. A fellow Team PWC member, Cheok-Yin Fung started series where she talks about popular and usefull CPAN module. Latest in the series is about Graph. If you like the idea then do share your comments and encourge her. I am so proud of her. I would also like to mention about the work recently done by Dave Cross i.e. Improvements to Planet Perl and Perlanet.

I am looking forward to the next big stable release of Perl which would bring the new shiny OO concept, Corinna among many other features. Ideally I would want to have v7 as it was suggested many years ago. I have no clue if anything is happening on that front.

If you look at the positive noises on so many social platforms, I am confident we are going to bounce back soon. We have best of the best talent, we just need guidance. I am sure, TPF can help us on that front too. So all you Perl Hackers, please don't loose hope. We would bring back the glory we once had. For now enjoy all the Perl goodies in the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
